Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, Kapitan! Isn't the Isle of Wight fantastic?
It's a great day to be here. Barely a cloud in the sky. You can't even hear the--
Look, you can still see some of my lightning in those clouds!
Well, that was fun. Race you to that crane, Kapitan?
Gah! I nearly forgot myself. Hmph.
Leaving the ship? Being on land? Well... I don't know that I could give you a satisfying answer.
Ha! Silly Kapitan. They do not have nearly the sense of humor you do.
*SEAGULLS*
Seagulls! Oh, Kapitan, I thought they'd been scared off of the coast!
It looks like this flock only just got the Morgana memo. There's work to do.
@BATTLE
Well, that battle solved our storm problem.
How exactly do you--
Belle, remember? You can't go that far from the ship.
What's it like, Kapitan?
*GASP* Are you secretly one of us, Kapitan? A Corka Juraty?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, you've caught me. I'm one of your lifeboats.
That's not what I meant.
No, it's just... a strange question.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, oczywiscie! I was just checking to see if you knew.
If you don't know something, why would it be strange to ask?
Why wouldn't I know?
I didn't know I could appear in human form until very recently. Who is to say you do not have a ship form hiding somewhere?
But you just said--
I say a great many things!
Right. I suppose... well, it's bigger.
Mhm!
Lots more people. You can go just about anywhere if you've got the time.
But I can go to more of the world at sea!
It's... not the same. I guess the biggest difference is that it doesn't move.
Well, that is simply not true!
What? Of course it is.
Then how do you explain earthquakes?
... Okay. Bad phrasing. How should I put this...
I think I understand now, Kapitan.
Land is *generally* immobile, you can walk on it, and there aren't fish.
We'd already decided that rivers don't count.
Not even the big ones.
Not even the- yes. That.
Why the sudden interest in land, anyway?
Well, it's not so much land as it is... a specific land.
You're still thinking about Poland?
Have you ever woken up somewhere you didn't expect to, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: Heavy question for you.

Fields.DialogueText: It is so heavy that I can barely hold it up standing in one place!
This is why I run when I think about these things, Kapitan. I am more likely to find a good place to drop them when my arms tire from carrying them.
But a Pole who has never been to her country - you don't find it strange?
Except in--

Fields.MenuText: Once. It was a long night.
I always know where I am. I have perfect situational awareness.

Fields.DialogueText: Ooh, like Achilles and her sisters talk about?
Hmm! That is something many Corki Juracie cannot say. It must be overwhelming, nie?
Not even close.
And I have carried this with me for some time. I... have never been to Poland!
Well, lots of people haven't.
I guess it is. But you've done a fine job bringing Poland here.
Przypuszczam. Some of it.
And you're doing a damn good job of defending it. It'll be there when this war's over.
... Hmm. Morganas, Kapitan. We should run to meet them.
Was it something I said?
@BATTLE
Siedem, osiem, dziewiec...
That's quite the bundle of letters. Taking up mail delivery?
Nie, Kapitan, but I would be quite good at it! They say I am faster even than Queen Mary.
But I have never actually raced her, you know. And she has traveled all over the world! What if she's learned how to be faster in her travels?

Fields.MenuText: I don't think that's how it works.
Only one way to find out!
Not bloody likely. I've seen your blueprints and design specs.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan! You shouldn't casually tell a girl such things! What would people think if I bragged about seeing your blueprints?
I don't have blueprints.
Well, if you did I wouldn't pry. Oh! That reminds me...
Then we'll have to get on a mission together! I'm going to write her once I finish responding to these.
I've found a whole sack of letters from my homeland!
There is still so much you don't know about us, Kapitan. There is still so much *we* don't know about us! I hate to disappoint my new pen pals...
Pen pals?
I'm surprised mail's getting through. You know, on account of...
Why, nothing can stop the mail, Kapitan! Even if these are a bit late.
How late are we talking?
Later and later all the time! They're covered in postmarks from all over Poland... Lithuania... Sweden... Britain... My, they've certainly bounced around!
From Poland to Britain... How'd the Home Postal Depot get their hands on them?
We'll have to think on that question later, Kapitan! The Morganas are coming!
@BATTLE
They don't know it yet. These just came in with today's mail!
They didn't! Or not recently, anyway. I found these in the hold after our last resupply in East Cowes.
So why there? Why us?
How do people sit still, Kapitan?
You didn't seem to have any trouble with it when you were putting your little Olympics together.
But that was different! I was racing toward a goal, tedious though it was! Like running through a minefield!

Fields.MenuText: You don't have a goal right now?

Fields.DialogueText: Sorting the mail, Blyskawica?

Fields.MenuText: That strikes me as more dangerous than tedious.
I don't suppose you could do that with this next round of paperwork?

Fields.DialogueText: I thought I'd sort it by date. Then I decided to sort it by destination. Then I noticed that almost every letter in the alphabet was represented by the surnames... You see my problem!
But it is tedious! You have to scan every inch of ground before you put your foot down, all while running!
I don't think normal people can do that.
They can if they practice!
But there's no doubt about it, Kapitan: we have a mystery to solve! Three, in fact.
I could, Kapitan, but the INPF will have to be fine with bean stains. I get hungry when I get bored.
How they all got to us, I suppose.
Tak, and where they are all going. I picked that one first because it's easiest.
We're still missing one mystery.
How we are to deliver them all ourselves, oczywiscie!
Blyskawica, I don't think we have the time to do that. Not with the war on. Can't we just hand them off to the military mail?
But then how will we know the letters reached their destinations? Nie, Kapitan, we must see this through ourselves!
It takes careful planning to intercept me. So if this responsibility falls into my lap, it must be mine to solve!
I wish you'd reached that conclusion when you were asked to help tidy the mess hall this morning.
Ah! I must have outrun that one. Never you fear, Kapitan - I've been here since breakfast! It should only take me--
*ALARM*
Well, cholera. Cleaning will have to wait.
Let's make sure some dishes are all we have to worry about.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, Kapitan! I've had a breakthrough!
I'll say. You ran straight through the bulkhead again.
Nie, I am through, but nothing is broken except for this mystery! These letters all passed through Gdansk!

Fields.MenuText: That can't have been recently.
Gdansk... Oh, Danzig?
What's that got to do with us?

Fields.DialogueText: You would be surprised, I think! Some of these are dated from the end of August!
That is the German name for it, yes, but its proper name is Gdansk! But that is not the point!
It's fallen right into our laps, Kapitan, so... everything!
If these letters came to us through the mail, then they must have expected us to deliver them.
And if we have to deliver them, that means we've got to get to every port on the Baltic that will have us!
And it's got to be us, because nobody is faster than me! Even Queen Mary cannot keep up!
Do you think she'd be willing to help? No, I am thinking she's busy moving soldiers around. It must be exciting to constantly have new people aboard, but they would never be around long enough to--
Blyskawica.
Blyskawica.
Blyskawica!
Gah! Kapitan, do not spook me like that!
I know you're only trying to help, but we've got bigger things to worry about than getting these letters to their destinations.
Some of this stuff is on our patrol route, but for the rest of it we'll have to let the military post do its job.
But it should be us doing this! I'm the fastest!
That's why they've planned such a busy patrol route. I hate to say it, but we're victims of our own success.
That does not sound right at all. If you succeed, how are you possibly a victim?
Let's discuss that after we clear out these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Kapitan! What's the English spelling for "conveyance?"
C-O--
All right, I think I've finally got this letter to Command worked out. Let's go visit Blyska--
Never mind, I figured it out! W kazdym razie dzieki!
And there she goes. Well, she'll be back.
Kapitan! I--
Blyskawica, I--
Nie, nie, you first.
I'm about to ask Command about our mail problem and I wanted to run this letter by you.
Swietny! Does your letter say that we have the situation under control and are ready to deliver the mail with all speed? Mine does too!

Fields.MenuText: I... yes. That's exactly what it says.
Quite the opposite. It's not our concern.
I'm guessing that's what your letter says.

Fields.DialogueText: I think that is not true. Kapitan, how could you lie?
Wait, how--
You look away when you are telling me something untrue. It is a look that says "My dear friend Blyskawica would cry if she knew the truth."
It is certainly my concern, Kapitan!
Such a perceptive kapitan I have!
But lying makes me cry as well. You see the dilemma. Do you want there to be a dilemma?
Perceptive and unyielding.
We can't do this unilaterally, Blyskawica. Our orders are to protect the world from the Morganas. We have people on our team keeping the mail running.
No, and I'm sorry I tried to slip one past you. But my point stands.
We have people on our team stopping it, too! Only look at Gdansk!
I... yes. I don't disagree with you. But it's not something we can afford to handle ourselves.
Hmph. This calls for more running and less talking.
It's admirable that you want to help. Can I see your letter, at least?
I suppose so.
... Blyskawica, I don't want to be rude, but this is illegible.
You try writing and running at the same time! Much harder than eating fasolka po bretonsku.
Looks like we've got Morganas. Don't lose that draft in the battle.
@BATTLE
Is that the disappointing letter?
Don't be so hasty, Blyskawica. We've gotten official permission from Command to hand off letters as long as their destination countries are on our patrol route.
We'll be offloading the British ones in Leith. And as luck would have it, there's a mail ship bound for Norway that leaves the week after we arrive.
This sounds less like permission and more like an order, Kapitan.
That's about the size of it. But the Royal Navy wanted to specifically thank you for finding the letters and keeping the mail going.
Well, I am always happy to help them!
Actually, you've been more helpful than you know. The Kriegsmarine also chimed in with thanks.
Co masz na mysli?
They cited our report to Command as instrumental in tracking down an intelligence leak in the Danzig area.
That... that was your report, Kapitan! I had nothing to do with it!

Fields.MenuText: I suppose if you want me to take all the credit, I will.
Different names for the same thing.
You had everything to do with it. You're the one who found the mail in the hold.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not trying to be humble, Kapitan!
Nie, Kapitan. Danzig is a very different place from Gdansk!
Well, now I almost wish I had not!
And it's Gdansk!
That's not the point. We've got better things to do than be a floating dead letter office, and it's favors like these that give us more latitude to do them in.
Nothing is dead as long as you fight for it, Kapitan. It's in our anthem.
That'll be us here in a minute. Let's move.
W porzadku. You should know that I'll be running for quite some time after the battle. Do not catch up.
Who knows what the Germans are doing because of what they learned from us?
Couldn't if I tried...
@BATTLE
Trzy... dwa... jeden...
... Cholera.
Zero!
*SPLASH*
Never took you for a swimmer.
One day I'll ask a submarine for lessons. Good thing I can teleport, nie?

Fields.MenuText: That'd do wonders for mail delivery.
If only you could do that with the ship.
I thought all Belles could swim.

Fields.DialogueText: Byc moze. But part of the mail delivery is the journey! I would hate to put Rawalpindi or Hermes out of business.
Only under special and very dangerous circumstances I do not quite understand.
It is less common than you would think. Most of us prefer to stay on top of the water.
Is there anything you need help with, Kapitan? I really must get back to what I was doing.
Listen, I wanted to apologize. I shouldn't have just brushed you off the other day.
I am glad you feel this way, Kapitan. I am sorry I did not talk to you about it before, but I hope you understand why I did not feel like it.
Right. You've got your homeland to worry about. It's hard not to.
To be away from your home and your people when they need you, even if you're helping them elsewhere... I wouldn't wish it on anyone.
Even someone you very much disliked?
I'll keep you in the loop with the decisions I do make. There's only so much I can do with my rank, but you don't make captain without doing everything you can. That's a promise.
I appreciate that, Kapitan. I would be a poor destroyer if I didn't do the same.
Even then.
... What *were* you just doing, anyway?
Well, the port is very close, but I can't quite manifest there and deliver the British letters myself. I was hoping to take it at a run!
And you hit a wall.
An invisible one! Good thing I didn't have the letters on me when I fell in the water, nie?
We've got Morganas prowling. Perfect opportunity to dry off.
@BATTLE
*KRACKOOM*
Not a cloud in the sky. Blyska must be restless.
That's just about everything I need. I wonder what Blyskawica's up to...
Holding everything down, Blyskawica?
Everything except myself, Kapitan! Are we leaving yet?
I know you've looked at the same schedule I have.
That doesn't make time go faster!
Multiple times, in fact. I got a nasty shock the last time I touched it.
Przepraszam, Kapitan. I know things tend to get staticky when I am bored.
But I am so bored! When do we move? When does the Norwegian mail ship leave? When does anything happen?
I know all the answers to these questions, but it is the waiting that makes me itch all over!

Fields.MenuText: You should have mentioned that before I went ashore. I think they make cream for it.
Just a little longer, Blyskawica. Once the mail ship leaves, so do we.
If you need something to do, just ask the crew what they need help with.

Fields.DialogueText: The itching is in my heart and under my skin, Kapitan! There is only one cure, I think, and money cannot buy it.
I suppose I can wait until then... but that does not make it feel any less like forever.
I did that just this morning, and within two hours I was done! Ninety laps later, here we are.
What to do, what to do, what to do...
As entertaining as that sounds, I doubt there would be time for that, even if you weren't already guaranteed to outlast the other sailors.
I learned at least that from the athletic competition, Kapitan. They may use proxies if they wish!
Perhaps... a marathon polka?
That sounds like a clever way to outdance even more sailors than you ordinarily would.
There is nothing boastful about it, Kapitan! I simply must use my energy or...
Or?
Well, I am fairly certain I will not explode. But electricity must be discharged once built up, nie?
Let's discharge it at those Morganas.
@BATTLE
Isn't this dance delightful, Kapitan?
If predictable, after the first few hours. How many people have tapped out so far?
Ah! But I remember now. I wanted to write Command about this graveyard of mail you mentioned.
The dead letter office?
Tak, that. The more I know about how these problems are solved, the better.
Well, I don't know if you'd be able to help them, what with our duties and all. But I'm sure they'd be happy to teach you about what they do.
I lost count around thirty. It is fortunate that I helped the crew with all their tasks, nie? Now they can relax with a marathon polka!
Their endurance will be all the better after! Just do that waiting thing that I hate doing.

Fields.MenuText: They'll need to relax *after* the marathon polka.
Mind if I cut in?
And if they're interrupted?

Fields.DialogueText: The next switch is scheduled for... twenty minutes from now! I'm sure there is still space for you.
Vigorous exercises before we start dancing again. It's not perfect, but it keeps everything fair.
*Huff* *huff* Miss Blyska... *huff* I think... *huff* I'm about done here...
You're just in time, marynarza! The Kapitan has generously volunteered to take your place.
Thank heaven.
Get some rest, marynarza. You've earned it!
Where were we?
On the verge of combat, unfortunately. Assuming you haven't run your crew ragged?
Oczywiscie nie, Kapitan! I am always combat ready.
@BATTLE
Says the fifty-four-thousand-horsepower competitor.
Mostly fair!
Goodbye, Leith! And goodbye, Norwegian mail ship! I hope you get there soon...
Don't worry, Blyskawica. The north Atlantic convoys are some of the best protected in the world.
Say goodbye to Leith, Blyskawica.
You are right, Kapitan. Any time worrying is better spent moving and doing things.
For example, I have been hard at work reading up on the ghost mail!

Fields.MenuText: You mean the dead letter office.
Now I'm wondering if Morganas have mail.
What have you learned?

Fields.DialogueText: Tak, but I find that name too depressing.
They do not need mail, Kapitan. They have... other ways to communicate.
Lots of things, Kapitan, and only some of them frustrating!
Do they really?
I could not tell you what they are, but they are there. It's very strange and I do not like to think about it.
Did you know that you are allowed to open mail if you need to find out how to deliver it?
I wasn't aware of that, but it makes sense. Sometimes people mess up addresses and whatnot. The things the post must find...
Hmm. I wonder how many people must find out about a secret before it stops being a secret.
There's not really a hard number. But as a general rule, the more people know about a secret, the harder it is to keep.
Unless you only share it with people who also want to keep it!
Well, those are hard to find. At least there are laws about opening mail.
I suppose if it made the difference between a letter being delivered or not... I would open it. But it would not feel right.
Hmph. Why must there be secrets?
Better people than either of us have pondered that forever. As long as humans want different things, they'll try and get one over on each other.
I suppose it would be boring if everyone wanted the same things. I just wish everyone wanted good things.
So do I, Blyskawica. So do I...
@BATTLE
Kapitan, Kapitan! Tell me Norway still exists.
All right, I've put off this after action report for too long. Pens up...
*BZZT*
Ow! Damn thing shocked me.
Which probably means...

Fields.MenuText: No. It's vanished from the map, a modern-day Atlantis writ large.
What kind of a request is that? Of course it does.
The mail can be slow at the best of times. It'll get here when it gets here.

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt any Norwegians would find that very funny, Kapitan! I know I do not.
Tak, I suppose so, but my imagination is outpacing even me!
Grr... I could circumnavigate the world in the time it takes the mail to cross the North Sea!
This Norway problem is sprinting circles around me. I have not yet received word that the corpse mail arrived in Stavanger.
Please don't.
Silly Kapitan! Even I do not have the range for that. I run sprints, not marathons.
If it's really weighing on you, Blyskawica, I can put in a message to the Royal Norwegian Navy.
But then how long would that one take? Ooh, this is becoming a problem I cannot solve by running or dancing!
Hmm... How's your handwriting coming? I mean while you run.
One of our sailors could almost read my last letter! And Polish isn't even his first language!
I'd work on that if I were you. I'm getting caught up on some stuff myself. It'll eat up the time before you know it.
Tak, tak. I just hope those people get my apology for the letters being held up.
You know, if I could use my electricity to make a typewriter float just right while I run--
That's a fascinating proposal for a less dangerous occasion.
@BATTLE
Doing wind sprints in the hold, Captain. She seemed agitated.
More so than usual.
Captain, it's the--
Belle, right. I figured. Where's she at?
*RUMBLE*
What the hell's going on down here?
*CHOOM*
I don't want to be electrocuted, Captain.
I'll handle this. As you were.
Yes, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: How long have you been at this?
You're scaring the crew, Blyskawica.
Blyskawica, what's wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: Czterysta piecdziesiat... czterysta piecdziesiat jeden... czterysta piecdziesiat dwa...
Minutes.
They would be scared too, if they had read the latest mail.
Only look at this message from Command, Kapitan.
Attack on Stavanger... driven off by the Royal Navy... Looks like Southampton's had her hands full keeping Norway safe.
But read further, Kapitan! The Morganas got the mail ship carrying the letters to Norway.
Oh, hell. Blyskawica, I'm so sorry.
It is not your fault, Kapitan. But  if I do not tire myself out down here, I'm afraid I may treat someone like it is their fault.
At least you're doing something constructive.
... Listen. About the other letters...
No time for that, Kapitan. It was the fault of the Morganas. I must treat them like it.
@BATTLE
I heard, Kapitan! We're going to the Baltic. And the Baltic means Poland!
Right you are. The Westerplatte's still a mess. They need someone in that area who can be... well, everywhere at once. Your name came up, in part due to recent events...
News from Command, Blyskawica. And I think you'll be pleased this time.
Do you see, Kapitan? My athletic competition was a success! Wherever my name goes, I will follow as fast as these legs can carry me!

Fields.MenuText: You couldn't possibly have planned for this.
They're not exactly on the hunt for long jumpers.
Here's your chance to show them Poland's alive and kicking.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not think I needed to! If you are fast enough, you can seize any opportunity!
They have never dodged a shell, Kapitan!
Oh, this is making me burst! Jeszcze Polska nie zginela, kiedy my zyjemy...
Slow down. It's good that you're excited, but this is for a week maximum until the Kriegsmarine can reestablish a safe zone. The North Sea's bristling with INPF right now, and--
A week!? We'll hardly have time to stop in Gdansk! We might not even resupply!
Believe me, I pushed for more. But the Royal Navy wants us back at Scapa Flow as quickly as possible.
I have nearly had it up to here with what the Royal Navy wants!
*sigh* But... bardzo dobrze. I should get back to training for my visit... even though it will be very short.
That's the Belle I know. You'll make the most of it, and Poland will be all the safer for what you've done.
What is left of it.
@BATTLE
Tak! It is so close! If I could only reach out and...
Still trying to push your limits, eh?
Almost there, Blyskawica. See the harbor?
I feel like a small animal running around and around a cage, Kapitan. Surely you understand.

Fields.MenuText: You're more than that. So much more.
I feel like that in my quarters sometimes.
Does that make me your keeper?

Fields.DialogueText: Tak, but in a very small package.
You need to do more work out where it is sunny and open!
Kapitan! For shame. You could not lock me up if you tried.
I doubt the wind would agree with my papers.
That is why you need to run! How else will you catch up when the wind blows your things away?
I'm aware. When was the last time you used the door to barge into my quarters?
Doors are optional!
Any letters to drop off in the meantime?
What will we do, Kapitan? Do you want to hand off Polish mail to some German kapitan?
Even if it got to its destination, it'd be all covered with those black spiders they like to wear.
You can't do everything yourself, Blyskawica.
Sometimes you must if you want something done right! Only look at what happened to Norway. If we had been there... ooh! I am going to wear a groove in my deck from running this off!
You can be the strongest and the smartest and the fastest in the world and still need allies to help you out.
Allies and... enemies of enemies.
Hmph.
*KA-KRACKAPOW*
Do you often announce yourself with lightning strikes on a clear day?
I do when I want enemies of enemies to stay out of my way.
@BATTLE
You should have been watching, Kapitan! There are some very interesting scorch marks on that Morgana right there!
@BATTLE
How's it looking out there, Blyska?
Keep up the good work.
Another fight down. It looks like they're backing off for now. Sweden can mop them up to the north.
Czy to wszystko? I thought the Morganas were getting stronger over time, not weaker.

Fields.MenuText: Even that hasn't been confirmed. Too early to tell.
Looks like your training is paying off!
We'll be out of here in no time.

Fields.DialogueText: If I can get stronger, Kapitan, then so can they.
One day I will learn how to shoot lightning, and then there will be no need for these silly shells!
Tak, and that is what worries me.
You're really outdoing yourself. You should be proud.
I am happy that I can show everyone how well we're doing, Kapitan, but we are doing too well to stay here for very long.
I suppose this is what it means to be a victim of one's own success, nie?
As soon as there's a mission that keeps us here for longer, I'm putting your name at the top of every list. There just isn't enough of a reason for us to stick around right now.
Nie, I suppose there is not.
... Hmm. Kapitan, will you run with me?
You'll leave me behind.
Tak, probably. Sometimes I do not know how you exist, moving so slowly.
We're moving at normal speed. You're the one who's fast.
I wish you could move at the speeds I do, Kapitan. To see the world around you slow to a crawl... you can do just about anything in the blink of someone else's eye.
Never thought of it that way. Well, there she goes... I'll see her again in a few seconds.
You wanted to see me, Kapitan?
Well, they don't know that. We're being detained in the harbor while they search the ship top to bottom.
Right away. I've got the Kriegsmarine *and* the Abwehr asking for me by name. Something about sensitive information finding its way aboard.
"Pursuant to assessment by Abteilung IIIN... reason to believe that your vessel may harbor seditious..." what the hell?
I have been out running, Kapitan! If anything had come aboard, I would know.
What could they be looking for?
Whatever their anonymous tipster sent them in search of. Know anything?
The last thing I want is to be searched by Germans.

Fields.MenuText: The *last* thing?
I want to believe you. You wouldn't exactly medal in lying.
Do you suspect anyone aboard?

Fields.DialogueText: I would not want this medal around my neck, Kapitan!
Well, the second to last thing. The last thing would be to not have legs.
Nobody, Kapitan! You should have been at more of the marathon polka. People get very loose-lipped when they are tired.
Well, regardless, make sure to cooperate with any questions you're asked.
Hmph. Do you think German Corki Juracie put up with these invasions of privacy?
I'm told many of them are active participants.
Well, they will have to catch me first!
They've caught us already, Blyskawica. You're a powerful Belle, but Command puts up with a lot when it comes to the Kriegsmarine. Their words, not mine.
Well, if being on our best behavior means defending Gdansk a little longer... I suppose I can live with it.
Ought to keep us in someone's good graces, at least...
@BATTLE
Gotowy... idz!

Fields.MenuText: You're not exactly keeping a low profile.

Fields.DialogueText: Gah!
Oof!
Ah, Kapitan! Have you come to help me get onto Polish soil?

Fields.MenuText: Explain to me how I'd go about doing that.
I was going to offer you some tea and a good book. You've clearly got cabin fever.

Fields.DialogueText: Just have the helmsman nudge me a little closer to shore every hour or so. The authorities will not notice if we do it right!
I do not feel too warm, Kapitan! No warmer than usual, anyway.
You're certainly giving our guests a show.
I started running from the port side, you see. One minute I was leaping overboard, soaring through the air... and the next I was crash-landing on the starboard side.
Looked painful.
I will have bruises in disagreeable places, Kapitan!
Why would you hide yourself from the world if you had my speed, Kapitan?
Whatever keeps you out of trouble.
Be glad I am about this task, Kapitan. I will be tempted to pickpocket our Kriegsmarine chaperones again.
That's funny, I thought you said "pickpocket." And "again."
I put their things right back in their pockets where I found them, Kapitan! When I am moving quickly enough it is like taking things on and off a shelf.
It doesn't stop being theft just because you return things.
Wait, speaking of returning things... Blyskawica, what did you do with those Polish letters?
Sewed into my skirt where nobody will dare touch them, Kapitan! I am an able seamstress *and* a world-class athlete.
Well, get them out.
How rude! I never took you for a scoundrel, Kapitan.
No, I mean... listen. We're trying to prove we have nothing to hide. Keeping those letters hidden isn't a good look, no matter what's in them.
Nobody will know if they just--
It's not like you've hidden your mail adventures from the crew. Remember how hard it is to keep a secret?
Tak... I know, Kapitan.
There's nothing important among that mail, is there?
When you say "important-"
Is there?
*Sigh* Przykro mi, Kapitan.
Wait, sorry for what? You don't mean--
You may want to sit down when we finish with these Morganas, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
*WHUD*
There was nothing to tip them off to, Kapitan!
You can say that again. I would have known if there were anything important in among that mail. You're not exactly the secretive type.
*You* tipped off the Kriegsmarine?
I can be for a few days!
Right. Long enough for the world's most humorless intelligence agency to go over us with a fine-toothed comb while we're interned at...
... Gdansk.
Kapitan, please do not be angry.

Fields.MenuText: If you weren't my Belle, Blyskawica...
I'd have every right to be, but it wouldn't solve anything.
You started an international incident for a visit home?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad I am. You are a patient kapitan.
I do not like being angry either, Kapitan. It is harder to run off.
It's not an international incident if they don't know who the culprit is! The leaker could be German for all they know.
If you'd just let me explain, Kapitan...
Please.
I was running the other day and writing one of my new pen pals, explaining the mail situation, and my handwriting's getting better while I run, but it's still not *that* good...
*THIRTY SECONDS OF BREATHLESS EXPLANATION LATER*
So you didn't even lie about there being secret documents or whatever in the mailbag. You just mentioned *that there was a mailbag* and let the chicken scratch paint a picture.
And then I made a paper airplane and threw it at a Nazi.
And things spiraled from there. I doubt they even know what they're looking for.
Tak. Just that there is something to look for aboard a Polish destroyer.
Kapitan, I'm so sorry. When I learned that we were coming home, I thought that if there really was a reason we could stay...
No, you've made yourself pretty clear. Let's keep making a good impression on our hosts.
@BATTLE
Coffee, Kapitan? You look like you need it.
Please and thank you.
*sip*
If I never have a meeting like that again, it'll be too soon.
All right. I got a look at that letter.
The one that caused all the trouble?

Fields.MenuText: I'll say. This will shake up the INPF's schedules for weeks.
Seriously, have you been pearl diving? You're soaked.
Look, it's going to be all right. You're needed out there. The Kriegsmarine know that.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja wiem, Kapitan. I was not thinking far enough ahead.
You first, Kapitan! You said!
Tak, all too well.
... Why are you dripping wet?
You first, Kapitan! We both have things that are frustrating us and I noticed first.
Again and again, the homesick part of me outruns the thinking part of me. This is funny, nie? The only one who can beat me is me.
Morganas. Long may that continue to be the case.
@BATTLE
All I can say is we're lucky you're a Belle. I doubt we'd be having this conversation if... well, you saw what Orzel went through in Tallinn.
But she *is* one of us, Kapitan!
That's still unconfirmed. The point is, our people are spooked, but even the Kriegsmarine is willing to admit that they don't have much to go on.
You see, Kapitan? It is all working out very-
*Pending* turnover of what letters remain.
In light of the Morgana threat and given the lack of corroborating evidence, they're prepared to lift our internment.
... I knew you had that look about you. The one that said "I am about to tell Blyskawica something very disappointing."
Cholera. I knew I should have stayed underwater.
Mystery solved... and yet not. What *were* you doing down there?
It was the only direction I hadn't tried escaping the ship.
I sailed out of the Baltic Sea two days before any of this started. Before the Morganas invaded... before the Germans invaded... before I awoke.
I promised that I would do whatever I could for you as captain, Blyskawica. But I promised honesty, too.
@BATTLE
The Corki Juracie are not of your world, Kapitan. But even so... my heart tells me my home is in that part of it called Polska.
If you overslept and missed the last ferry that would ever bring you home, you would feel as I do.
Come on, Blyskawica. Give me the letters.
I will, because I have to. But I do not want to yet.
Every day we're stuck off the Westerplatte is another day somewhere else doesn't get the help they need.
What about my country? Where was the rest of the world when we needed help?

Fields.MenuText: Where was the world? Where were *you?*

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know, Kapitan! I couldn't tell you if I wanted to.

Fields.MenuText: You're not holding the war hostage over a sack of mail.
Fighting for their homes.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not at least get an answer?
It is not right that anyone should have to fight for their home. If the fight is over... I just thought I could at least visit.
Is there one that would satisfy you?
*sniff* I know what I did was wrong, Kapitan. I am still not sure I would not do something like it again.
Tak, and you did not get it in return.
That's something I cannot outrun.
No, you can't. But you can run toward something better. And that starts with letting this go.
Very well, then. But you are helping me take apart the skirt I keep the letters in.
Let's calm the sea down before we pick up any seam rippers.
I have to, Kapitan! Most human-made clothing would catch fire or rip right off at the speeds I favor.
And you know this how?
Damn, you really sewed these in here good.
Southampton told me! She is very good at clothes. If she were here she'd have all these letters out of this lining in a few heartbeats.
All these letters that have been far too long undelivered...

Fields.MenuText: It's been some weeks. A few more days won't hurt.
It's not your fault, Blyskawica.
Poland has more to worry about than mail disruption right now.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like the sort of thing one says again and again over many years.
It is not... and yet it also is.
Tak, tak, I know. But that is beyond us. If any small thing were to cross our path that I might help with... well, just look.
Wait... this one's addressed to... Norway?
Tak.
I thought we'd had these delivered.
Do you remember the writing I was getting up to during my running, Kapitan?
I think you also thought that they went down with the mail ship off Stavanger.
All right, cards on the table. Is there anything *else* brewing that I should know about? You didn't send Hitler a mail bomb set to explode on the first of the coming year or anything?
No cards and no brews and certainly no bombs, Kapitan! Just... just me being afraid of these letters crossing one more ocean without me.
It is horrible, but after Norway I felt like I had done the right thing hiding these letters.
And now here I am cutting them out of a skirt to hand over to people I would rather not. A victim of my own success, nie?
Myself... and everyone who these letters are addressed to.
And if we are a mail graveyard and we can open envelopes...
All right, I'll spare you the lecture. You've obviously put a lot of thought into this. Just...
Cholera! We will have to save the lesson for when the battle is over, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Whatever you were about to say, I agree completely!
Never change, Blyskawica.
Here they are, Kapitan.
All the letters in the bag?
All the ones we had not already delivered.

Fields.MenuText: Do you feel lighter now?
Finally we can get out of here.
Let's agree not to discuss those. They're between Germany and Britain now.

Fields.DialogueText: I feel like I am weighed down by something different. But if it does not weigh you and the crew down, I suppose it is all right.
Looking around... I understand now, Kapitan.
Whatever makes things not as difficult, Kapitan.
Look at it this way, Blyskawica. Would you have wanted to stay interned here in... here in Gdansk?
In a free and Polish Gdansk, I might not have minded so much.
But here with unfriendly flags and unfriendly people watching my every move...
Even if this was my city, it is not the home I dreamed about.
I have been thinking, Kapitan, about what a home is.
I think it is somewhere you are glad to return to... and yet free to leave.
And where we are right now is not that.
Blyskawica...
When the Kriegsmarine or the Abwehr or whoever come to get the mailbag... may I hand it over myself, Kapitan?
As long as I am doing things that are hard, I should also be doing that.
I don't see why not.
There's nothing you can't do, Blyskawica. But if you really feel like you need it, you can warm up against these Morganas. Looks like they're testing the perimeter we helped build.
It will hold as firmly as my stitching, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Perhaps those people will get their letters after all?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
There's Blyskawica. I'd better ask her how she's-
Dzien dobry, Kapitan!
Do widzenia, Kapitan!
- doing. Well, she looks like she's back to her old self.
Ha! I think I have beaten my two-hundred-lap dash record by eight seconds at least!

Fields.MenuText: "At least?" You're not sure?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I'm always glad to see you making progress.
I got distracted and melted another stopwatch.

Fields.MenuText: Next time a Morgana challenges us to a footrace, we'll be ready!
Think you can break the sound barrier?

Fields.DialogueText: Silly Kapitan! You should see how I build up static charges with my speed.
One step at a time, Kapitan! I need to master running on water first.
And look, say what you will about the Abwehr - they're good at finding people.
Just you wait, Kapitan! I am possibly getting strong enough to leave the ship!
Perhaps not tomorrow or even next year, but the energy within me... it feels more boundless every day!
I'm not sure that makes sense, but I don't think it has to. It works for you, and that's all I need to know.
Tak, tak. And as powerful as I become... I will let you and the other humans be powerful too. In your own ways.
We can't do all the good in the world, Blyskawica, but we can sure as hell try.
I feel it every day. It's a wonder my sidearm doesn't explode in its holster.
I am reasonably certain that is not how it works.
Ooh! Do not forget the part where we saw that Morgana's skeleton!

Fields.MenuText: You're going to be getting a lot of questions from a lot of scientists about that one.

Fields.DialogueText: Dobrze. Here I am.
But in the second place I submit my wildest and most desperate of convictions, felt only as an answer that comes unbidden to mind before someone says it out loud.
Help is coming.
To whoever finds this letter:
The gates of Poland stand fortified against God only knows what. It won't be enough.
Yet here we train and fortify, with three chests of grenades and barely enough guns to arm a platoon of postmen. With this we are expected to greet the Pomeranian Army once Gdansk is relieved.
You don't choose where you fight for your country, but one hopes for a different battlefield than a post office.
Whatever mailbag this letter is found in, God willing, will be on the fastest ship out of the Baltic before the shooting starts.
It is a handful of sand thrown from an island in the path of a tidal wave... and yet it moved.
Should a free and noble soul find this message, I can offer them only two things: first, the knowledge that all I can do I have done; that someone somewhere was doing something.
I think that's just about it for this after action report.

Fields.MenuText: That's going to keep me up at night.
Can you do that more often?

Fields.DialogueText: As long as they can pronounce my name, I will take them over those British reporters any day!
Ah, then you can join me on my evening runs!
Not on command, but I am learning more and more every day!
All right, time to go do some captain things. Taking it easy?
I am taking it very easy and writing to some new pen pals in Britain. The first response to those letters just came back!
All thanks to you.
All thanks to the post, Kapitan. I will let them do what they do best, just as they let me run and fight!
That's the Blyskawica I know. I'll see you for dinner, then?
I am looking very much forward to it!
Przykro mi, Kapitan. But I am glad that one letter was missed. It was not addressed to anyone, so I doubt anyone will miss it.
Whew! Alone at last.
